Params: Assets/Product/Texture/Image/BgStory/BgStory46.jpg

President Hassen announced a 30-minute break from the World Government's executive meeting due to the unexpected message from Karenina. Liszt must find enough reason to support his proposal during this time.

Liszt puts down the very brief incident report sent along with Karenina's message. It only mentions a Punishing Virus leak accident of unknown reason in the lunar base, which caused the zero-point engine to go haywire.
Liszt
We can't let her destroy the zero-point engine...
Norman is leaning on the door with a big frown. He has never looked so serious and anxious.
Norman
Hey, didn't you hear that girl from the Engineering Force...? Everyone on the Moon will die if they don't destroy that whatever engine!
Liszt
It's only one possibility... Besides, we can't know if that Engineering Force captain was telling the truth.
Liszt crosses his hands as if he is thinking of something.
Liszt

Karenina had a lot of contact with Collins on the Moon. He seemed to like her too... She even had private conversations with that agent. Who can guarantee she isn't acting like this because Collins was just stripped of his power...?
Liszt
A Punishing Virus outbreak just when we submitted the proposal... Is it really a coincidence?
Norman knows very well that Liszt's words were provoking, but he still has a point.
Liszt

Besides, there has never been any sign of the Punishing Virus on the lunar base over the years. When the zero-point reactor was activated, no virus was detected either... Not to mention all the checks were conducted by Karenina herself.
Norman
There was a serious incident on the Moon before I was born... It was suspected to be caused by the Punishing Virus. Perhaps...
Liszt

That was nothing more than a speculation. The only survivor, Dr. Kalon, was out of his mind... No evidence could link it to a possible leak of the Punishing Virus. Very few people knew the truth anyway.
Given Collins' more senior position, he might know the truth. But it does not matter anymore, for Liszt has zero interest in what happened in the past.
Norman
But my sister is still on the Moon. We can't afford to take the risk...
Liszt
Don't get it wrong...
Liszt's low, serious voice interrupts Norman.
Liszt
She's no longer your sister. You have only one sister now, which is Victoria. Don't forget that you are representing your family. Think twice before you speak.
Liszt gets on his feet and walks to the door.
Liszt
Just stay here if you can't watch the Parliament make their decision. I'll take care of everything... myself.
Norman clenches his fist, but can only swing it toward the cold wall.
Norman
Dammit...
Assets/Product/Texture/Image/BgStory/Bgstory427.jpg
The break is over. All the participants have returned to the parliament hall. Almost everyone is discussing Karenina's recording and report, each with their own intentions.

Hassen looks around and goes back to his position as the host. He clears his throat, and the hall gets quiet over time. But it does not mean the argument is over—the real battle is only about to begin.
Hassen
Based on the meeting protocols, I hereby announce that the World Government executive meeting is changed to an emergency meeting to discuss how we should respond to the sudden crisis on the Moon.
Hassen
First of all, I'm quite certain that Councilman Liszt would like to explain, right?
Hassen nods at Liszt, giving him the podium.
Liszt
The report was sent by Karenina, the Engineering Force captain. Neither she nor we have any clue how the Punishing Virus was produced or how it caused the zero-point engine to go haywire.
Liszt
The comms are completely cut, so we are unable to get further information from her. I don't think we have sufficient information to make a rational decision.
Liszt's words remain unbiased, but he has a clear objective—to calm everyone down first. He trusts they are rational enough to understand what Babylonia's best option is.
Liszt

But there is one thing I would like to urge each and every one of you to carefully consider before making any decision. The zero-point reactor was made by our best scientists after numerous sacrifices. It is the dream machine that will guide humanity toward the future of hope.
Liszt
Right now, we have an opportunity to reach that future. Are we really going to destroy it with our own hands?
Liszt
Are we going to neglect all the sacrifices humanity had made in the past?
Liszt
Are we stripping all humans of their rights to reach for their hope in the future?
Liszt's question forces all the council members to put humanity as a whole on the scale. Even those who insisted to destroy the engine earlier have begun to hesitate.
Liszt
That is why I am firmly against the destruction of the zero-point engine. I hope this can become the foundation of all subsequent discussions...
He has been secretly paying attention to Hassen and Nikola but does not see anything unusual. He thought those hawks would be in favor of the destruction of the zero-point engine.
Perhaps even they have to admit that the benefits of the zero-point engine outweigh the cost. He has won.
Excuse me. Sorry, I'm late—actually, "we" are late.
An elderly but still vigorous man calmly walks into the hall, followed by two young individuals.
Liszt
(Collins... I knew he wouldn't give up easily.)
Liszt saw Collins coming and prepared for it. He gives a signal to his subordinate in the Control Court.
Control Court Member

Mr. Collins... If I recall correctly, you are currently under internal investigation for the unlawful imprisonment of the Gray Raven Commandant. You are not qualified to take part in World Government meetings. President Hassen, I suggest we...
Before the meeting started, Collins was told that he would be put under internal investigation for the inappropriate "imprisonment" of the Gray Raven Commandant.

He was certain that he did not leave any evidence for Babylonia. Even if they were after him, they didn't have to wait until now. The only possible explanation was Liszt had been planning this all along to set him up.
Collins
Excuse me, you probably got it wrong. I have no intention to become part of the meeting. These two young people have never been here, so I was just showing them the way.
Liszt finally shifts his attention to the two behind Collins. One of them is Simon, the commandant of Dark Aries, while the other is... the Gray Raven Commandant?!
Collins

I know I'm currently forbidden to sit in a World Government meeting, and I have never been in one in the past anyway. Still, as the Chief Military Advisor, I think I still have the right to refer someone.
Collins gives Hassen a meaningful look until Hassen nods.
Hassen
Of course. I trust it is in our common interest to see more trusted young people being referred to this meeting.
Collins
(Damn old fox...)
Collins smiles. He knows that Hassen and others would strongly oppose him should he have referred anyone else today.
He has been keeping the referral as a trump card, but he has no other option now and can only bet everything on the Gray Raven Commandant.
Collins
I'd like to invite them here because they have been through numerous battles on the frontline. They are the experts in making such decisions.
Collins
In particular, the Gray Raven Commandant is our "hero" who has participated in various difficult missions. I'm sure the opinion of this commandant means a lot to everybody.
Collins
There was a little misunderstanding between the Gray Raven Commandant and me, but we still developed a great friendship during our conversation...
Collins
Oops, I'm talking too much. Well, it's time for me to go. I'll leave it to you.
Collins leaves his final words before walking out of the meeting hall.
Collins
Don't let me down... Gray Raven Commandant.
Simon
Um, Chief... I've never been in a meeting like this...
Me neither...
Simon
I feel like I'm going to throw up...
You are not used to being the center of attention either, whether it comes from the Corrupted... or from the questioning eyes of the humans that are supposed to be on your side.
Just think of them all as Corrupted.
Simon
Then I'm going to pass out...
Simon finally forces a smile... Thanks to that Kurono man, the two of you are standing on this unfamiliar battlefield instead of fighting the Punishing Virus.
Assets/Product/Texture/Image/BgStory/Bgstory524.jpg
Hours ago, that Collins guy rushed into the treatment room of the Star of Life. Nobody dared to stand in his way except Dr. Hippocrates.
It's the Kurono officer that Nikola warned you about—given his behavior, it is near impossible to not recognize him.
Collins
You're the Gray Raven Commandant, aren't you?
Hippocrates
They are all my patients... And who are you? One more step, I'll crush your frontal lobe.
It's okay, Doctor. We'd like to have some time with him.
Hippocrates
Fine... You have 15 minutes. I'm not taking responsibility if you get worse.

After she left, Collins explains the situation in the Parliament and Karenina's work on the Moon. You don't know how much you can trust him, but the information about Karenina and Luna sounds quite credible.
What will happen if we don't destroy the zero-point engine?
Collins

According to Karenina's report, not only everyone in the lunar base will die, the gravitational waves will also send rocks flying toward the Earth... Then it won't be a matter of single or double-figure casualties.
Collins
If everything goes according to Liszt's plan, nobody will speak for Karenina. Even if she can destroy the engine and return, they will probably pin some charges on her.
After all, destroying the zero-point engine without permission is a serious crime. If Liszt decides to make a big deal of it, Karenina will not get away.
The worst part is that it will hurt the military's trust in the Parliament and may even stir up conflicts between them.
Simon
I've been paying attention to the meeting. Just like Mr. Collins said... most of the voices were supportive of Liszt's proposal.
That's why Simon asked if I knew a Construct named "Karenina". He was already aware of what happened.
Collins
How ironic... The "hero" they raised to guard against me is now the only power I can rely on.
Sorry, but I have no reason to help Kurono.
To your surprise, Collins does not seem to be worried at all but smiles instead, as if he knew you would be giving this answer.
Collins
You won't turn me down... Just like Karenina, you cannot sit and watch if other people are in danger. If the Parliament is a battlefield, only you can save them in this war.
What's there for you to save Karenina and other innocent people?
Obviously, this man would never do anything without benefit. Even when he is driven to the edge, you must find out his exact purpose to avoid any potential repercussions.
Collins
Hah, how cautious of you. In fact, I couldn't care less about Karenina and others on the Moon. She means nothing to me after completing that huge Omega Weapon...
Collins
But just like I said earlier, I firmly believe that agent named Luna is the key to humanity's future evolution. We must not let her die in vain on that deserted Moon.
Is that a theory you believe in?
Collins
No. In fact, it's my instinct... When you get older, you learn that simple instinct often makes more sense than complicated calculations.
Collins
I trust it is a necessary sacrifice for the greater good. Not only Karenina, I would not hesitate to sacrifice my entire life just to find that answer.
Collins
But you're different. You are a lot greedier than I am... No matter how dire the situation is, the first thing on your mind is always to save everyone and everything.
Collins
Honestly, I thought it would be only a matter of time before your kindness got you killed. But you proved me wrong every single time, dammit...
Is that so? I'm sorry.
Collins stands up next to the bed and reaches out his hand.
Collins
Just like what I told Karenina on the Moon, Ascendants aren't necessarily always the enemies of humanity. Neither is Kurono... Only frailty is.
Collins
If you and I are both too weak, why don't we join forces at least for now?
Utilizing all available resources is a basic principle of tactics. Even enemies can and must be used if necessary.
(Hold out your hand)
Collins laughs boldly, shaking your hand and ignoring your vigilance.
Collins
Come, "hero"... Show those people that you are capable of saying more than nice words. Your speech will be our sharpest edge.
Assets/Product/Texture/Image/BgStory/Bgstory427.jpg
Hassen
Gray Raven Commandant... From what I recall, you only just recovered from a serious injury. Are you fit for this?
I'm okay, President Hassen.
The wounds are hurting so much that you must lean on Simon to stand still. But the pain gives your mind clarity.
Hassen
In that case, we shall let the Gray Raven Commandant speak first. Is that okay with you, Councilman Liszt?
With a frown, Liszt eventually nods... But he obviously is not giving up.
Liszt
I too would like to hear Gray Raven Commandant's opinion on this sudden incident.
Taking your hand off Simon's shoulder, you slowly walk up the podium.
Assets/Product/Effect/Prefab/FxUi/FxUiStoryNew/FxUiStoryWhiteNew.prefab
Assets/Product/Effect/Prefab/FxUi/FxUiStoryNew/FxUiSHanshuoNew.prefab
Assets/Product/Texture/Image/BgStory/BgStory0.png
Assets/Product/Effect/Prefab/FxUi/FxUiStoryNew/FxUiStoryWhiteNew.prefab
Assets/Product/Texture/Image/BgStory/Bgstory427.jpg
Just when you walk on the last step, you suddenly feel a sharp pain in the wound on your head. You have to hold yourself up with both hands on the podium.
Assets/Product/Effect/Prefab/FxUi/FxUiStoryNew/FxUiSHanshuoNew.prefab
Simon
Hey... Chief!
You quickly signal Simon not to help as it will only expose your frailty... But it seems too late. The wolf already has his eyes on the prey.
Liszt
Don't push yourself too hard, Gray Raven Commandant... This might not be a battlefield, but that's no reason for you to overexert yourself.

He has seen through your camouflage and is determined to completely crush your confidence. The two commandants may have been through a lot of battles, but on this battlefield, you are not much different from rookies.
Some council members are already getting impatient. To them, letting an inexperienced commandant speak is a pure waste of their time.
Liszt has always had the upper hand. No matter what you do, you can't seem to easily shake his argument.
But that can also become your advantage. The enemy will only expose some weakness when they think they have already won.
Thanks, Councilman Liszt... But aren't you the one who is overexerting yourself?
Liszt
Me...? Sorry, but I don't quite understand.
You need to remind everyone of the one thing that Liszt has been avoiding...
(The security of Babylonia)
(The safety of zero-point energy)
(The security of the lunar base)
(No... Liszt isn't concerned about that. Think again)
As an outsider with almost no preparation or foundation, you need to attack the opponent's weak point first. Even if it can't take him down, you can still drag him into a skirmish.
The data obtained from Atlantis successfully helped the lunar base to reboot the zero-point engine. However, are you able to guarantee it is safe to use?
Who can guarantee that incidents like this will not happen again when we are actually sailing in the vast universe? Without the Earth to back us up, we have no means to deal with it.
Liszt

Your worry is unnecessary. The restart of the zero-point reactor has been verified both theoretically and physically. No Punishing Virus was detected in the vacuum chamber throughout its booting and running.
So Karenina must have confirmed the results. You mentioned earlier that she was the expert in zero-point energy research, which gave the project a lot of credentials.
Liszt
Of course, all the data collected in the experiments is still valid. My proposal is based on this evidence.
Then why are we not trusting the decision she made on the spot?
While we are here talking, they are fighting death and disaster, over and over!
Liszt's deep eyes stare at you. He seems to be thinking about how to spin the argument back on his side.
Liszt
In her report, Karenina also stated that she could not guarantee the destruction of the zero-point engine would definitely stop the disaster. It might even cause more dire consequences...
Liszt
If both options have their risks and I have to pick one, I would prioritize the zero-point engine.
Even at the cost of the lives of those on the Moon, and more innocent people on the ground?
Liszt
It's a "necessary sacrifice"... To me, all the sacrifices are worthy of our one and only hope. We can't be naive and think we can survive this world without any sacrifices.
Liszt
As the Gray Raven Commandant, you know this more than anybody else... That new specialized frame was used by one of your Constructs. Her name is Liv, I believe.
Liszt clenches his fist as he speaks to all the council members in a calm and firm tone, increasing his credibility even further.
Liszt
She knew someone must make the sacrifice. Someone must become hope... Without the sacrifice, humanity may never have their future... Right now, the zero-point engine is the only hope!
Sacrifices must be made for our only glimmer of hope... No one has ever doubted this axiom, but what truly is hope?
(The zero-point engine that takes us to the future)
(The last Eden, Babylonia)
(The people who create hope for us)
(That's no different from Liszt's "hope"... There must be another answer)
Assets/Product/Texture/Image/BgCg/Cg2801_06.jpg
I think the real hope isn't a new specialized frame, or the zero-point engine itself... It's the people who created all of them.
We lost our home, but we can take it back. We suffered many losses, but we can learn from them and never make the same mistake again. Even in a world of despair, we can create miracles together.
Humans are not strong, but we aren't so weak either. A hope left by the past cannot make us give up thinking or stop going forward.

The new specialized frame is a new hope created by the people and Liv together... Compared with a zero-point engine that can be remade, I would rather trust the people who create hope in the lunar base.
The flow of the meeting begins to change. More people start to discuss and think about what you said.
Assets/Product/Texture/Image/BgStory/Bgstory427.jpg
Hassen waves at you, then walks to the center of the conference hall, facing all the representatives.
Hassen
I think that's plenty of discussion. The Parliament needs to make a decision regarding the crisis that Karenina and the lunar base are facing.
Hassen
Let's leave the final decision to all the humans. No matter what the result is, it will be a "future" chosen by the entire humanity. I hope everyone can think carefully and make your own decision.
The hall is lit up by countless glowing spots that represent all the Babylonia residents, followed by a synthetic voice from Gestalt.
Gestalt
The decision has been made...
